I have to say though, that the menu was not very clear on what was vegetarian and what was vegan. An Burger item said "vegan grain" but it was not vegan. 

To top things off, there was dip n dots in here! That was one of the highlights of my day.
column2164:
We visited Woodland Zoo on a Monday which greatly helped with crowds. It felt like there weren't that many people at the zoo throughout the whole day. When we got to Rain Forest I think there were only 5 or 6 tables being used with no lines for food. 

I had the double cheeseburger and it was not bad. The prices aren't the cheapest and I'm sure they do it because they're basically the only restaurant place inside the zoo. Pacific Chowder wasn't nearly as big / nice and it was outdoor seating only. 

I'd be hesitant to visit the zoo on the weekend.
column2165:
My boyfriend & I decided to stop by the RFFP as a quick break while we were at the zoo. We went around 1 pm. It was SUPER packed inside. I think it was really busy just because it was Sunday & lunch hour too. 

Interior: 
Inside was spacious. I was able to find a table quickly but I could imagine that some would find it hard to find a table if it was even more packed than it was today for me. There are several other food courts in there to choose from.

Exterior:
I was going to sit outside since it was lovely weather but the tables are really dirty with bird poop everywhere or birds staring at you waiting for a chance to steal your food haha. 

Let's get to the food part now! I ordered the Clam Chowder Bread Bowl & my boyfriend ordered the cheeseburger with a BBQ sauce inside with a side of waffles fries, onion rings & a soda drink. In my opinion the clam chowder was okay, not too bad but the bread was kind of hard & didn't taste that good. The clam chowder bowl was about $9-10, I would say the bread bowl isn't worth it so just get the clam chowder. My boyfriend said his burger was good & his onion rings were crispy but his waffle fries were soggy. His combo meal was around $11. 

Final verdict: 
We both say this place isn't too bad to eat at as long as you're not expecting extraordinary food. It's mainly geared for little kids since they're most familiar with these types of food. It wasn't too expensive either. The only drawback I saw at this food court was how it wasn't the cleanest because most of the tables were sticky or covered with crumbs of food from previous customers. There should be more servers to clean up inside & outside tables. Second con is the long wait line as well. 
So I would give a 3/5 *
column2166: Decent food. Fries and pretzel were nice and salty, however, we wanted the hummus plate and they were out. Disappointing. I like that I can drink beer at the zoo though.
column2167:
As far as Food Court/Pavillions go at a place like the zoo, this place is da 'bomb!

Where can you buy a giant icee (slushee) and get free refills on a hot day?  Here!

Where can you find a variety of kids' meals sure to please the pickiest of kids?  Here!

Where can you find TONS of tables, with air conditioning, to eat even if you only brought your own food?  Here!

Where can you get a variety of items from paninis to pizzas to waffle cut fries?  Here!

So basically, I have never been to a better food courtish like option at a BUSY place like the zoo!

The floor to ceiling windows and tons of natural light let you see and enjoy everything happening around you.  

The washrooms were plenty, clean, and had change tables!

And there were videos playing wtih animal facts - like did you know that Gorillas co-sleep and breastfeed typically until around the age of 4!  

LOVE love LOVED the Woodland Park Zoo and the Rain Forest Food Pavillion will definitely be my regular stop in the future :-)

See you later Alligator!

P.S. Yes, prices are high, it is the zoo... but definitely cheaper than say DisneyLand food ;-)

P.P.S.  If you like garlic, try the garlic fries!  SO Garlicy good!  It will definitely keep the vampire bats away ;-)
column2168: If you absolutely must eat because you forgot to pack a snack, the food pavilion is will save you. If you can wait until you leave the zoo, Phinney / Greenwood Ave have much better options. The "safe" fried staple items like waffle fries are . Everything else is overpriced for what you get. I can't recall why I placed an order for their Seattle Dog. Anyway, check the photo for an idea of what you'll get. This was the first time where appearance actually affected my appetite.
column2169:
The foods are 8-15$ which is quite expensive for what it is. I got a double cheeseburger Combo for 15$. The burger was quite good, but the fries were cold and tasteless. My sister got one of their bacon flat bread, and it was cold too. The drink that come with it was a small cup. The bread was thick and soggy from lots of tomatoes sauce on it. My 2 kids who normally can finish a large Papa murphy pizza could not finish the small flat bread from here since they did not like it.

Overall, it was not bad considering it's just a restaurant in a zoo. I would recommend their burger not any of the flat bread. Buying food at prime location like zoo, airports or theme park is expensive. Set the right expectation so you won't be so disappoint.
column2170: This is a great Zoo. It is too bad who ever is running their food service is completely inept and should be run out of town. Not only are the workers rude but they have no idea how to basic hospitality functions. It was embarrassing to witness having been in hospitality for over 25 years
column2171:
The Rain Forest Food Pavilion is the food court located inside Woodland Park Zoo. Typically food courts aren't overly impressive, but this one is actually pretty legit. There's a ton of seating, both inside and outside. They offer a fairly large menu with a wide variety of options for the entire family. Vegetarian options are labeled on the menu. 

Service is quick and friendly. Not exactly a destination spot, but if you're already in the zoo it's definitely not a bad option.
column2172:
I feel like writing about amazing food at a zoo food court is supposed to be against the rules...like discovering amazing art in a bathroom or something. But I digress, this place was a knock it out of the park find that left all of us very surprised and satisfied!

Large seating areas, including a ton outside. It's basically split into a pizza line and everything else. They have a surprising array of offerings here, from some really good salads and paninis to the standard burgers and hot dogs. The sandwiches we had were crazy good for a spot like this and were more than ample in size. Plus, they only ran around $8 - it was cheaper than going out to a sandwich shop in town and just as good! We had a chicken apple salad with produce from over the mountains and it was tasty!

Pizza slices were huge and something kiddos can split - another thing we're not used to finding at spots like this.

Overall, this was an incredible place to grab lunch and it didn't break the bank. They run things very efficiently and had some really nice offerings. Lines were a little long, but not unruly. Definitely worth checking out when you're meandering around the zoo!
column2173:
The Rain Forest Food Pavilion is located in the middle of the Woodland Park Zoo in Seattle, Washington. It is basically a cafeteria in amongst the exhibits on the west side of the zoo itself. 

The Rain Forest Food Pavilion has a large communal seating area and contains five different "restaurants": 
1) Corner Pizza sells pizza by the slice and ICEE's
2) World Taco, with what you might expect 
3) Market Grill harbors burgers, fries, hot dogs, onion rings
4) Woodland Deli boasts freshly made sandwiches, salads, soups and entrees
5) Zoo Java has espresso, smoothies, ice cream, cookies, popcorn, and pretzels

As you can probably tell, the establishments in the pavilion are very much catered towards kids and their taste in food, along with a little something for the adults in tow. As a family, we had opted for a burger with homemade potato chips, garlic fries, waffle fries, mac and cheese, a Korean taco and a cherry ICEE to wash it down. As a very pleasant surprise, the trophy Wife brought a Cheese Panini with Bacon Jam and potato salad, which might be the single best panini that I've ever had! I'm not against paying zoo admission again just for another one of those!

Overall, the food was actually quite good, for cafeteria food. The homemade potato chips were also a stand-out for me. They were warm and crisp but I would have liked a side of dipping sauce of some sort. The garlic fries were also very nice and the portion was more than enough for the four of us. 

It was unfortunate that the mac and cheese was basically Kraft dinner. Granted, it was cooked well and my seven year-old daughter was happy, but for $6, Daddy wasn't quite as impressed. Also FYI, straws are not available, apparently due to the danger factor for the animals at the zoo. Initially, I was annoyed at this and thought it was a bit of overkill, but after thinking about it, I completely understand and support the zoo in their decision to keep trash as minimal as possible and protect the animals from any potential hazards.

I really liked the fact that if you buy an ICEE, free refills are available at the self-serve machine. Four ICEE's kind of made up for the pricey mac and cheese. 

The pavilion has TV screens that advertised the zoo and had facts on many different animals, which I thought was a very nice touch, while providing information on the activists and the conservation of these various animals.

The men's room was nice, clean and big and had a little bench for tired fathers that don't necessarily want to stand at the urinal with their little wrangler.

I would definitely take in the Rain Forest Food Pavilion again, and urge anybody to partake in the Rain Forest Food Pavilion's goodness, and not just because it happens to be on the zoo property. The experience was quite good and I give it a solid four stars.
column2174: After going here twice over the last year, I believe they have changed their menu selection. I thought they had more vegetarian options before, but I would enjoy seeing some in the future. The onion rings there were pretty over done, but the fries were done pretty well. They have almost ball park prices for food and drink, but at least here your money goes to the park as well as restocking the shelves, so at least your money is going to a good cause. The waits can be a little long during the busy days, but they stay pretty organized with delivery. Would still return, but I would pay a premium for a vegan or veggie Chicago dog.
column2175:
Food and service were both terrible today. We've eaten here in the past and the food was always hot and edible, service quick and friendly. Nothing fancy. Today my vegetarian burger was cold and wet (yes wet). The party was waterlogged and falling apart. The waffle fries were plentiful but bland, cold and hard. They forgot one of our sandwiches and had a hard time understanding what they missed and how to make up for it. They finally subbed it with a smaller sandwich rather reluctantly.
Kids Mac n cheese was a tiny bowl of shell pasta cooked in cream, it had no flavor. 
The only thing good was their pizza. 
Not worth shelling out so much money for such awful food, unless all you want is pizza and ice cream.
column2176: Your typical attraction food court with burgers, pizza and fries. Drinks are extra expensive ($4 for medium soda).
column2177: Not good food.  Everything was way too salty except for the fries which didn't have any.  Everything was 2x expensive as it should have been.  Giving 2 stars instead of 1 because the staff was pretty good for the most part
column2178: If it's a busy day be prepared for long lines and cold food with embarrassingly slow turn around time for your food.  What can you expect for inflated prices and a mismanaged food service though.  I'll pack a sandwich next time.
column2179: This is barely on par with a middle school cafeteria at 4 times the price. The pizza is like those $5 pizza specials from a guy driving around in a truck, except the only give you one piece. The hot dogs cost the same as in the stadium but are overly steamed to kept warm and the bread is gross.
column2180: I was really impressed by some of the smells coming from the pavilion when I walked in to use the restroom. Sadly, the taste did not live up to the anticipation. My wife had the pizza, and it tasted like microwaveable pizza, which is not terrible if I'm on the couch in my undies playing some Xbox. But for a nice family outing at a zoo and for $7 I expected a little bit more. I had the chickie and waffle. The chicken was delicious. I highly suggest it. The waffle was delicious I'm sure...three days ago, when they made it fresh. Today, the waffle was stale, hard, and cold. I do not highly suggest it. In fact I suggest staying away from it at all cost. The staff was also a bit blasé to be polite. They seemed way less than thrilled to be there, which I totally understand because hey, it's work! But come on, try to fake it a little. I mean, a fraction of a second of eye contact would be better than the comatose stare into the abyss I got from many of them.
column2181:
I have always loved Thai Tom, and over the years they are still consistent and awesome! Thai tom is very vegetarian friendly! And the peanut sauce is sooo good! 

Ordered take out during covid. It was ready for pickup in 15 mins. Good precautions to ensure minimal external contamination!
column2182:
Used to be absolutely the best Thai anywhere.  Still 5 star, but Something has changed lately though not sure what.  Still VERY good after all these years.  Pad Thai is the standard.  Love the crunchy char on the noodle that comes from the super hot wok and al dente preparation.  

I used to love sitting inside at the counter.  One is no more than 3 ft from the fire, and it's amazing to watch and smell aromas as the chef prepares the food.  Now with Covid, we get take out, and the food is still good, just without the "show."
column2183: Our go to no-frills thai food! Bean sprouts tofu, panang curry, and fried rice are favorites! Only downside being no delivery and only cash. Would order much more frequently if they did delivery!
column2184:
I wish we had a better experience here, but unfortunately that was not the case. After seeing several reviews noting the steady decline from its heyday, we weren't as excited to try it out. However, we were in the area and said "what the heck!" and went for it.

With the current restrictions, customers are not allowed inside the restaurant and instead are to place their orders through the small window out front. I thought that was a great way to keep social distancing and facilitate orders as quickly and smoothly as possible. Given the location being on a busy foot traffic street, this would allow people to place their orders and stroll around the area as they wait.

Out came a lovely lady who was also giving take out orders to hungry customers. I have to say I was surprised that she came out the door rather than open the window. Seemed counterintuitive, but no biggie.

We went with their tofu pad thai, since that was one of the dishes that they're known for. Paid cash, and after 10 minutes, our order was ready..super fast! We jetted back to our car and headed home looking forward to chomping down some noodles.

At first glance, it didn't look anything like other pad thai dishes we've had. That's okay..looks can be deceiving and everybody has their own way of making this street style dish. Took a bite and other than the spice level sending a surge up my nose (!), the flavor was completely off. There was no hint of tamarind, fish sauce or anything that is normally in pad thai. The noodles were burnt to a crisp which wouldn't be bad considering the char flavor enhances the tamarind/sugar/fish sauce base, but since it wasn't there, it just tasted burnt and crispy. There were vegetables in there that aren't traditionally there and they looked old and felt like an afterthought. Tofu was old as well. Portion was embarrassing even for 1 person, yet alone 2.

Overall, it just missed the mark. I will give them kudos on their choice of PP 5 plastic container for their food orders, which is better for the environment.

In any case, it's unfortunate this is how it came to be, and I know so many businesses are hurting right now, but food has gotta be better than this! I hope things improve for them, but we won't be back anytime soon.
column2185:
I really wanted to like this place, but the way they served my curry take-out was simply mind-boggling. I really should have taken a picture of the set-up but generally, you know how Thai places separate the rice and curry into different containers for take out?

Thai Tom literally COMBINED the rice and curry into a large Styrofoam container, so the rice was completely soggy by the time I got home. Moreover, the rice:curry ratio was rather ridiculous, essentially a mountain of soggy rice, with a sad puddle of curry in the corner. Will not be returning.
column2186: Okay, this has been one of my favorite Thai spots for a while now in Seattle. Their menu is somewhat limited but every entree is the same price. They are a CASH ONLY restaurant. The last 2 times I picked up food there, I was a little disappointed. Last time I picked up some pad Thai and it just didn't have the wok hei (breath of the wok?) that it normally had and a lot of my noodles were clumped up AND the chili was not distributed evenly. The time before that, I ordered the panang curry (second time) and it wasn't good at all. Not sure if they changed cooks or quality control just went bad? I'll probably go back again, but if it's not good for the third time then I probably won't go back anymore.
column2187:
I seriously love Thai Tom. If you've never been here and you're in the U District, do yourself a favor and just stop by. 

I will say that the service isn't the best and it's cash only (no prices on the menu either lol) but it's all part of the experience. It's such a tiny place that they literally cook the food in front of you. I feel like it's a college version of Benihana. Haha! 

I come here a lot and here's what I've tried:

- PAD THAI (10/10): this is probably the closest I've tasted to street food in Thailand. I prefer it with chicken or just veggies. Be sure to ask for extra chili powder and the green chilies if you want some extra spice. 

- THAI CURRY FRIED RICE (8/10): it's pretty much what you'd expect, it just lacks consistency for me. Otherwise great option if you like curry and fried rice. 

- THAI TEA (9/10): it's good, just sometimes a tad overly sweet 

- THAI COFFEE (6/10): it'll be honest - it's not my favorite drink I've had. It was interesting, but I won't get it again. It tastes like they added coffee to Thai Tea, which is why I thought I'd like it. 

I definitely stop here almost every time I'm in the U District! If you like Thai, give it a go!
column2188:
I have been coming here for 8 years now. My husband is a big fan. He came here since first year of college. The wait here to dine in always take forever, like about 30mins to 1 hour standing in the cold. But if you go by yourself or togo, its so much faster. 

I have tried almost everything on the menu. I love the Thai salad, its not on the menu. I also love fried tofu (mostly because of the peanut dipping sauce) pad thai and swimming rama. Their food are all flavorful, but more on the sweet side. Sometimes I think its not neccessary to be this sweet. There were two times my food came out very salty (2 stars spiciness), salty to the point that I felt sick after. Their food burned most of the time but I guess I like the burn flavor from the big fire. 

The restaurant is dirty, I dont think they clean often. The service here is terrible. They will rush you out for the next guests and also cash only. If the tip is not at least 10%, there will be a reminder from the server hahaha but I dont care cause its good.
column2189:
So good!! I never understood the hype for Thai Tom so I never really went when I was here for college. I'm used to seeking out the wok/charred smell of Thai/Asian food cooked in high heat("wok hey" if you know the reference) and this place does satisfy it ! Portion-wise, it is relatively smaller than most places in Udistrict - but the taste does make up for it.

Pad Thai, Pad see ew and pad kee mao (Drunken noodles) are all solid choices!
column2190: Covid times review - they have shortened their menu (totally understandable) but they have drastically reduced the food quantity and also the veggies they would add in any of their meat dishes.. we have ordered multiple times and everytime our panang curry would come with very few brely 2-3 pieces of chicken and very few bell peppers (sometimes none).. this is not the Thai Tom i was willing to drive to enjoy amazing thai food.. its now a normal thai place (the food is still good the sauce is flavorful) but i wouldnt want to drive to eat such a mediocre meal.. I miss my old thai tom food!
column2191:
A friend recommended this place and some youtuber highlight this as a must visit place. I didn't even read the reviews anymore but I should've. Was kinda disappointed, taste wise I can tell the cook wasn't paying much attention to how hot the wok is. Some can make burnt fried egg into art and tasty but this is not the case. 
Probably The time I came, it was already a different chef therefore the taste wasn't as people would raved before.

Local seems to be okay with the taste. I see lots of regulars. Friendly service and thoughtful price.
Curry fried rice tasted more of like a burnt egg with little curry flavor. I asked very spicy, but it is not spicy at all.
Thai fried rice - tasted ok, could've use a little more soy sauce... again, fried egg -burnt.
Pad see yew - this probably taste more decent than the first 2.

Thai ice coffee is great, enough to keep me up driving to our next stop. 
Thank you Thai Tom! 
I appreciate you for being open during my visit.
column2192:
I would wish I could give Thai Tom 4 stars but the quality isn't quite there anymore. I've been eating Thai Tom for over five years now and it used to be my favorite Thai restaurant in the greater Seattle area.

The positives:
* The chefs are always working hard and efficiently so the food is prepared fast for how busy it gets (usually 10-15 minute wait time before it's ready)
* It's a neat experience--you get to watch the chefs cook your dish in action if you get seated at the raised table on the right
* Plenty of options to choose from (including vegetarian food)
* Flavorful and spicy level is customizable (but be careful, it tends to be on the spicier side)

The negatives:
* The value has gone down over the years. The food still tastes great but with the price increase they actually give you a smaller portion compared to what it used to be.
* There's limited protein options: chicken, tofu, and shrimp (extra $1). There used to be beef and pork but looks like they put it off the menu.
* The wait can be long (average is 15-45 minutes before you're seated) 

Although Thai Tom has changed a bit, I still enjoy coming here whenever I'm on the ave.
column2193:
Located in UDistrict, this place has been a hot topic amongst my friends. Personally, we thoroughly enjoyed our experience of the chef cooking right in front us in a tightly spaced restaurant. It felt cozy and "interactive" in a way - we sat elbow to elbow. 

Quick note: it's cash only. We luckily sat next to a nice person who gave us cash for Venmo. There is an ATM nearby I believe. 

We got two different curries: panang with tofu and thai curry fried rice. We shared them, and they were both delicious! I'd definitely come back to try their other dishes.
column2194:
(cash only)
Thai Tom is a small restaurant on the Ave that is known to sometimes have a line - and for good reason! It is a really good shop! The interior is kinda small so I'd recommend only if you have a small group of 2 if you want to dine in. A lot of people like getting takeout so that's an option too! 

Their curries have always been solid in my experience! I recently enjoyed the Kung Fu w/ chicken (#8 on menu), which was a bean sprout stir fry over rice. 

Definitely going to keep coming back here!
column2195:
This restaurant epitomizes 'hole in the wall' - seats 15-20 people with the food being cooked on a blazing wok right near you.

Food: (5/5) Excellent! I eat here about a dozen times a year, and while I do end up ordering the same stuff, I have consistently loved all the food at Thai Tom, to the point where I crave it! Highly recommend the Pad Thai (I get it with chicken *and* veggies) - it is not the usual sweet stuff other American-Thai restaurants serve, so expect a bit of a kick. Also recommend the curries and the cashew chicken. *Vegetarians* - everything can be done with tofu/veggies; if you don't like or are allergic to fish sauce, call it out very explicitly because they tend to rush through taking and cooking the order.

Ambience: (3/5) On the fence. It's weird rating a place like this for it's ambience because that isn't their intended USP. It is supposed to be a tiny, authentic no-frills place and not always the cleanest. Recommend going with a max of 2-3 people if you want a seat in less than an hour. Late afternoons on weekends are better than peak lunch time.

Service: (2/5) Meh. This is an area where they could do so much better. While the service is super fast and mostly able to handle crowds flocking outside the restaurant, the servers are not pleasant and sometimes even rude. That being said, know that I will be going again and again and again for that 5/5 food :)

Note: Thai Tom is cash-only; with 2 entrees and 2 thai iced teas, it usually ends up being $35.
column2196:
The Thai Tom of January 2020 through (at least) May 2020 is not the same Thai Tom as before--what happened?

Perhaps ownership change, management change, or a philosophy change? Who knows, as I won't continue to speculate. What is known is that Thai Tom's food quality and service (already a low bar) has deteriorated to notably lower levels.

To start, phone orders is the only way to place an order here during the pandemic. You will often be put on hold for more than 10 minutes (up to 20 minutes on one occasion). If you're lucky to get an order in, the wait at peak times is communicated as one hour. OK--acceptable. What is not acceptable is when you arrive the restaurant one hour later and rudely get told you have to wait an unknown amount of time longer for the food to be ready. 

Great--you now have your food. The food these days is dry, sometimes burnt to a crisp on noodle edges, and varying levels of flavoring (sometimes too salty, sometimes very bland). This was never the way Thai Tom of 2019 and before was. That is too bad. 

For those of you who haven't been to Thai Tom in 2020, please lower your expectations and be cautious. The food is still acceptable; it's just not the same as it was before.
column2197:
Overall Thai Tom is okay. Their food tastes really good, but the service, communication, and overall experience are poor. Lemme explain...

First off, I hate writing negative reviews. If you look through my reviews here and on my YouTube series Seattle Eats (by channel Sub7 Fitness) you'll see that this is my very first one below 3 or 4 stars. So yenno when I write one you know it's serious.

The wait for my order was 24.5 minutes. That sounds reasonable... typically when you order in or call ahead most places would say 20-25 minutes. But let me preface this:

Thai Tom is an Ave favorite. On The Ave most restaurants will have your order ready within 10 minutes, especially if you order less than 3 things. I ordered two.

In addition to this, 4 parties that placed orders after us were served before us. Including parties that ordered the exact same two dishes as us. Each time that someone who ordered after us was served before us made me a little more angry.

There was no communication. 

Literally, they could've just said it'll be 20-25 minutes, and that would be problem solved. But they didn't. They never gave an estimated time and with no one else in line ahead of us I thought this would be typical ave wait time.

In addition to this I ordered two items at $10.75 each and was charged $25. So I believe they included tax and tip when they gave me the price. With no receipt, I couldn't tell you how something that should've been $21.50 became $25 before tip.

My dish (drunken noodles) was delicious. My fiancé's dish (pad see ew) was not so good. It wasn't necessarily bad, but there is much better pad see ew out there (including two blocks away at Noodle Nation). 

All-in-all it was unfortunately a bad experience.
column2198: Extremely rude customer service when ordering over phone,  when they said cash only I went to check my wallet and he asked if I'd been there before and I said yes but many years ago and he said what like ten years ago? I didn't understand how that was helpful to anyone and came off as rude. Thai food was good but not the best, def not good enough to go back.
column2199: DO NOT SPEND YOUR MONEY HERE! The servings are tiny so it's honestly a rip off. Most of my garlic chicken was rice. There were about 3 small pieces of thin, dry chicken in the whole dish, and maybe 2 pieces of uncooked broccoli. The noodles have a horrible, mushy texture and taste like sweet cardboard. The fried rice, and frankly everything else, had barely any flavor. I read the 3.5 star reviews before deciding to order Thai Tom, thinking it had to be mostly good ratings considering there were 2,200 of them. I was such a fool! They also only accept cash which they didn't notify me of before I gave them my order. I've never had such bad and disappointing Thai food.
column2200: I get dreams about the Thai curry fried rice I ate here. Best fried rice I ever ate. The food is so good that I'm okay with wait times and the 'Only cash' policy.
column2201: Fantastic Service! We were made to feel right at home. Well spaced tables, covid procedures followed to a T! We enjoyed the in house Country Fried Steak and Amazing Challah Cinnamon French Toast. I think we found the new Beth's! I saw Onion Rings as big as your fist arrive at another table. Can't wait to go back again! Go, read their menu! 3 eggs! Who does that? North Star does!
column2202: Why didn't i find this place earlier?! I loved their space themed deco and the funky patio. Tony was super friendly! He even offered to morph my picture into the astronaut wall of fame! I had the vegetable hash as snack. Like how they had the spicy mayo around the edge which gave the root vegetables a kick. Keep it up with the space force amid pandemic. One day when you see some asian female astronaut on the wall, you then know what's up lol
column2203: I stepped in here the day before all the restaurants were ordered to close due to COVID-19. Sat down at the counter, and ordered french fries. Ate them one by one, squeezing a line of ketchup along each one as I did so. The fries are tasty. Not sure if they are housemade or not, but they are robust and you literally do get one pound. I took the rest home and ate them later. A pleasant final meal in a restaurant for a while.
column2204:
I used to be a big fan of this place until today. If you are a fan of real chicken fried steak for breakfast, this is no longer the place. They have replaced the real cube steak with a pre formed meat product patty.

I'd also like to note that their formerly great hash browns are not anymore. They used to come with well grilled crust and obviously parboiled potatoes. Now the potatoes inside are raw. 

I don't know if they've had a change in kitchen management to cause these quality issues, but the least they could do is change their menus to remove the real cube steak boast, which is clearly deceptive.
column2205:
FRENCH TOAST STICKS. nuff said! 
Great no frills diner, excellent safely precautions, and friendly service. Huevos rancheros were delicious, coffee was great! Very cool astronaut decor. Will return!
column2206:
With all the hype, I really expected better food.  It was Fathers Day and  this was my brother's choice!   He is a pretty terrific dad and spectacular grandad, so this day he gets what he wants. 

To start out being positive, the staff is delightful and they do a great job of being friendly while keeping the space clean and inviting all day long (and night too, I hear).  

The character of this place is unique. The decor has something for everyone. (lol) Classic diner furnishings complete with booths and a counter at which you can dine.  The menus are those massive plastic menus that seem to always have something stuck to them but ours were sparkling clean.  

Looking across the dining area the  first thing I noticed was a wall FULL of portraits of our astronauts. ( I would have liked a closer look at these but I feared the booth diners might think I was being intrusive ;)   A clockwise glance took me into space with a full wall mural featuring a galaxy.  A glance upwards is a  tray ceiling that definitely has an Asian theme.   Some might say the decor lacks continuity, but I prefer to think of it as a time capsule, offering a shout-out to the establishment's history. ;)

Fish n chips, if it is on the menu, I am going to order it. Besides, I am in Seattle, right? They should have good fish here , was my thought.    The first bite was perfect. Crispy on the outside. On the inside there was a beautiful chunk of cod done to perfection.  I was tickled.  The fries were gorgeous.   Perfect  cut and perfect doneness for me.  The potatoes are cut with skins on and the fries were delivered while pleasantly crisp. 

Then not so good!   
As the fresh hot food cooled, both the fish and the fries turned totally soggy right before my eyes. ick!!!  I am not sure why this happened, I am supposing  the wrong frying oil?  not fresh frying oil? but whatever the reason, it was a buzz kill. 

What remained outstanding was the coleslaw.  Excellent coleslaw!  I am pretty fussy about my coleslaw so this is a big endorsement.  
Alas, parking costs more than the coleslaw, so I would not recommend you make the trip for just coleslaw. :) 

Sorry guys!
column2207: Eggs benedict!! Yes! Also the Huevos Rancheros are huge! Big coffees and larger portions. Nuf said! Try this hip eatery and you won't regret it.
column2208:
So close to being good...but not there.

Went on a Saturday morning and bypassed the people waiting for tables to sit at the bar. The food took a really long time (but came out in order from when other people ordered). The shrimp and grits were good, but the grits had sat just a little too long where they formed into a polenta blob. Still really tasty but not quite the right texture. They were, however, really tasty and paired well with the shrimp/sausage. The blueberry Pancake was fine, nothing special. The breakfast burrito was promising, but it was so incredibly oily. The tortilla was literally shining and was gross to pick up. 

We would come back, because it seemed like it was more of an execution issue, instead of flavor.
column2209:
There is something special about North Star Diner & Shanghai Room.  Perhaps it's the 24/7 eatery, serving classic breakfast entrees or the dim-lit bar with cocktails and boozy milkshakes.  But I'm a fan.  

I met my friends here for dinner as they love North Star Diner and are lucky enough to live walking distance from this place.  After coming here for a breakfast dinner I can see why they and many others frequent the spot.  I like the casual vibes of its space theme in the diner and the more intimate Shanghai Room next door.  Staff were also super friendly here. 

For dinner I ordered the Chicken Fried Steak plate because you can get this bad boy at all hours of the day, including dinner time!  I don't often eat breakfast food, but the chicken fried steak was di-vine.  The meat was tenderized, so as to easily cut it, with just a butter knife, and I really enjoyed the country gravy smothered on top, with a bed of hashbrowns underneath the steak.  I also ordered my eggs sunny side up, which made my meal all the more yummy, with its runny yolk, creating its own sauce. 

Come for the breakfast food, stay for the drinks and atmosphere.  Located in Greenwood, North Star Diner & Shanghai Room is truly a treat and one that all Seattleites must check out, especially at night.  Plus, it's Anthony Bourdain-recommended, so, you'd be a fool not to.
column2210:
I love the people and the food. Quality diner fare with some creative but not pretentious options. Build your own breakfast burrito yields amazing creations. Great music, interesting decor, stable staff who are real people. We love you Northstar!

Hey, haters: they recently updated their decor including new/more comfortable seats, etc.
column2211:
Have you ever heard people talk about old Seattle, the way it was before the tech giants took over and raised everyone's rent a million dollars? They make Seattle sound like a sleepy fishing village, going at an easy pace, with no cares, where everyone has a caffeine addiction and a perpetual hangover, and everyone is playing rock and roll. That's pretty much this year place in a nut shell. 
If you go to their website and read their story, you'll learn that this humble hipster eatery was once a local land mark Chinese spot, loved by the locals, but it was lost during The Boom, along with a number of faceless names. Most of which are now apartment buildings. So they decided to keep some of that old Seattle here. Changing very little other than the menu, this breakfast diner moved right in serving right on the original plates. This place has a quirky ness for sure and the employees look like the  members of an indie band. When our server came to the table it took me a few seconds to realize they were here to take my order and not some random guy questioning my musical tastes. The decor is mostly still from the old Chinese restaurant but they have given it a weird space vibe which is fitting for the city with the space needle (another randomly space themed thing). 
The staff were all very friendly. The food was fresh and tasty. The environment welcoming and fun.
column2212:
Amazing options for a place that is open 24 hours! I wasn't aware there was any place offering decent food at all hours of the day. Thanks to the late Anthony Bourdain for visiting in the Seattle episode and bringing this place to my attention. My friend and I were super hungry after seeing Little Shop of Horrors at Shoreline College and were looking for some comfort food. North Star Diner truly has something for everyone. Our server was really sweet and attentive, making sure to answer all of our questions before taking our orders. 

I ordered a salad with the dressing on the side and it came slathered in dressing - hungry and not wanting to be a complainer I suffered through the meal. When I told the server at the end of the meal he asked why I didn't say anything right away - I explained not wanting to waste perfectly good lettuce and that it was okay. My only suggestion is that the chef put less dressing on salads as one can always add dressing later but nothing can be done with an overdressed salad. I also pointed out that the salad should have come with avocado and it had none. He apologized and brought out half an avocado in slices so I could enjoy the last bit of the meal with them. 

I'm guessing the cook that evening was not familiar with the menu descriptions as it was also supposed to have tortilla strips but actually had wonton strips (totally different texture/flavor than what I was expecting for this salad). All of this is to say it wasn't the fault of the server and he was lovely through and through. The kitchen could probably use some closer attention to detail later in the evenings, but I am still looking forward to visiting in the future to try out other menu items!
column2213:
Mmmk. So. I was a little torn on how to rank this place. So when I give it 3 stars, I really do mean "A OK". 

The place is neat--they have a whole wall of astronaut portraits! (Though, I never did find Leland Melvin's dog portrait. Their shirts are rad and I still super want one even though my experience was less-than-stellar.

Service was EXCELLENT. Our server was great. If I was rating on service alone, it would've been 5 stars. 

Unfortunately my food was... not rad. To be fair, I probably shouldn't have ordered a bunless burger at a diner... but it was just... a bummer. The patty was super small and thin. The guac it came with was the consistency of jarred baby food. My fries were quite under-done. 

My friend who I was with got the biscuits and gravy, and it looked GREAT. (Unfortunately I can't eat it.) my other friend's sandwich looked GREAT. (But I can't eat that either.) (Though, he said his coleslaw was bad and didn't eat it.)

All in all, I'll certainly give this place another chance someday--but definitely getting breakfast food.
column2214:
3 AM trip to a diner after bar hopping? this is typical for me, i live in the diner state (jersey). However, after seeing this dine on one of anthony's bourdain's show, i kjnew it was worth a trip. At first i was a bit skeptical, its basically a big open room with painted walls and framed photos of the astronauts in the USA. Kinda bare and empty, but you sit down at the booth and get a menu thrown at you. service was okay, wouldnt say it was too fast. however..the food...

i ordered the french toast and all i got were 3 big slices of french bread slices. at first i was a little disappointed, but i completely judged. the french toast was out of this world. fluffy inside, slightly fried outside crust. it was hot too! my friend got the green eggs and ham hash and she was practically licking her plate dry. prices are very generous, portions too. 

ps they serve alcohol but stop at 2 am.
column2215: We came to this place to get breakfast and they were PACKED. So instead of having us wait, they said we could head over to the bar section (which is open 24 hours) and eat there if we wanted. It didn't seem ideal at first, but in the end, couldn't have had a better experience. The Shanghai room was so unique! On top of that, the breakfast burrito I had was life changing. I highly recommend this place!
column2216:
Not a clean place to eat....
I'm sure it is an ok place to drink alcohol and not be aware of your surroundings. Food is bland and tasteless- overpriced.
Think insane asylum cafeteria.
Furniture is sticky, mismatched and unlevel.
Don't get me started on the smells.
column2217:
North Star Diner- a go to for a late night/after drinks/I'm drunk breakfast food.

One of the most helpful and reliable late night grub-if you want breakfast at 3am in the morning but make in feel home made. 

Give this one a shot, and let me know what you think
column2218:
Good spot for good diner food. They have a huge menu, literally something for everyone. This includes breakfast, lunch and dinner 24/7. They have a general selection of beers, including some local options. For dinner I opted for the Rueben sandwich. It was good, but honestly could have used a little more meat. The fries it came with were good as well. 

The interior is very eclectic and unique. Service was quick and attentive. Overall, it was a good stop.
column2219:
We came here last Friday around 6 for a friend's low key birthday get together. For a place featured on an Anthony Bourdain show, I thought this place would have been PACKED on a Friday evening. We were pleasantly sirprised when we had ample seating and things weren't too loud.

We easily found seating for around 12 people in the lounge. It is really interesting to have this dark red, sultry lounge just opposite their diner. It's definitely a cool vibe inside with a 360 bar in the center. Best thing is that happy hour goes till 7 pm and has great deals on cocktails, beer, wine and food. Service was slow (lack of enough bartenders that evening) and they sometimes forgot our orders but they were super gracious about getting it made or fixed right away.

Cocktails are made very well. They look great and taste great. Some are too sweet for me but others were just right. You can taste fresh fruit juices. Happy hour prices are only $6 a cocktail vs $9-$12 normally. They even do tiki style drinks like their version of a singapore sling. I particularly liked their signature drink, the Northstar.

The lazy susan drink ( 8 random shots on a giant lazy susan turn table for around $45) was cool to see but shots were not strong.

The food was pretty good. I got the HH fried buffalo cauliflower and the french toast sticks. Soooo good. Freat flavor and so crisp.

Karaoke was fun after but the DJ could have done the audio better. Need to up the support music to drown out terrible singers like myself lol.

Really fun place with great drinks and food.
column2220: Anthony was on the nose with this place! It was wonderful, from the food to the ambiance and staff... I loved it all. Who can say no to 24/hr breakfast and home made soy sauce?? It's the little touches that go a long way... like a celery cocktail! I went with the spam/pineapple/egg option. It was good. The fried cauliflower was also great.
column2221:
Ordered the chicken teriyaki bento via UberEats and it was delicious! The chicken oddly reminded me of filipino chicken adobo with whatever the way they marinated it and seasoned it. It even looked like chicken adobo just cubed and minus the sabaw (soup). 

Portions were good for one person! The only con was the edamame got cold when it got to me which is expected with delivery.
column2222: Wonderful shrimp tempura roll! Nice and crispy shrimp. Also yummy spicy salmon poke bowl. Avocado was sliced right ripeness. Beautiful presentation. Petite portion sizes with high quality fresh and decadent ingredients. Takeout was easy and ready in 30 mins. Nicely packaged with access to condiments and utensils. Would visit again.
column2223: Really good - had rolls and the sashimi salad and been getting takeout quite a bit since Covid. Really great, wish they opened at 11:30am...I hate to wait until noon to order lunch!
column2224:
They failed to put any utensils with my order or soy sauce.
Very frustrating!!!!!!! Expensive delivery and 2nd time this has happened!!!
column2225:
Stopped by to picked up dessert for a friend's birthday. Ended up picking up the tiramisu and matcha dessert cheesecake for her and the mochi's for me. The mochi's I have to say were AMAZING...the texture and right amount of sweetness just melted in my mouth and I can see going back to pick up more. Will have to ask my friend what she thought of her desserts. I have tried the tiramisu before when a friend brought over and remembered it as pretty darn delicious.

The gentlemen who greeted me at the store was warm & welcoming & helpful. He gave me great suggestions on desserts and also informed me of their patio availability and happy hour info. He definitely encompassed what great customer service and care means, and was a great representative for the shop in my opinion.

I look forward to stopping by in the future to try their food menus as well as pick up more mochis
column2226:
This is the sweetest Japanese restaurant. My daughter and I were starving after going to the zoo and playing in the park for hours. We happened upon Modern Japanese and decided to eat here. When we first arrived the only two tables in the front of the restaurant were taken, so we briefly sat at the sushi bar until one table cleared. 

I ordered chicken karaage for my daughter, salmon nigiri and another roll, which I can't remember now, but in that moment, it was good hehe. Everything we got was delicious. Simply, but tasty. The karaage was soft, portion was small, so my daughter ate it all. Salmon nigiri was good piece of salmon. Overall, I was happy with our meal. 

Our server was friendly. People were in and out with orders, but otherwise it was just our table and another table for the duration of our lunch. The space was nice and clean, including the restroom. I believe there is outdoor seating for when it's warm out. I'm rarely in this area, especially now that our zoo membership is expired, but if in the area, would love to visit again.
column2227: These are fucking Oscar Meyer hot dogs NOT "Japanese pork sausage".  If your business is suffering that bad from COVID just take it off the damn menu. Shame on whoever was working today for the bait and switch. 1st and last time I will ever eat here. Sushi was stale too....
column2228:
This place is kind of small, have a nice backside for couples of tables maybe 2-3.. I was recommend by family in Seattle to come to try this place, we ordered a few rolls and a rainbow poke to try.  The sushi rolls were just ok, nothing very memorable ( I just remember how I didn't like the lion king, the cooked salmon in it was very fishy and combined with the shiso leaves gave me a weird taste)

Their rainbow Poké was ok, I felt their fish were a little slimmy and fishy tho.
column2229: After reading some raves on the Ballard Facebook groups we checked this place out this week. It was so delicious!!!! We ordered via the phone and get were super nice and we picked our food up ourselves. Everything we ordered was fresh and so yummy. I got the salmon bento box, it was so cute and good. We got sushi too and it was really great. We will definitely go back!
column2230: I tried take out from Modern a few weeks ago while i was in the area. Seemed a bit pricey for the small portions I received, but im wiling to try again in the future with different menu items. It was hard to resist the dessert options!
column2231: I was really disappointed in our meal. The portions were exceptionally small. We were shocked when we opened up the tiny containers. For $85, I expected to be able to feed a family of 4 especially given that two of us are younger children. Everyone was still hungry after all the food was gone. And it wasn't even good. The udon was bland as was the sushi itself. The kara-age fried chicken was lukewarm and doughy, not crispy. We've had kara-age in Oakland, CA before that was amazing. This felt like kara-age from McDonalds in comparison. What a bummer. Will not be back.
column2232: Honestly, I'm hard-pressed to find good Japanese food near me, but this place is phenomenal! I had the Dragon roll and it was SO good. We also ordered the Unagi bowl and the eel was amazing and melted in my mouth and just overall was so yummy. The desserts were equally great. We ordered the matcha cake roll, baked cheesecake and tiramisu cup. The matcha cake roll was fluffy, the cheesecake dense and creamy, and the tiramisu sweet and flavorful. Bonus: super cute decor :) 10/10 would recommend!
column2233: I didn't have a good experience at this restaurant despite  the other people high ratings. The server seem like he wasn't experience in the F&B industry and the food was lacking,especially my tempura udon. The only reason I am giving it two stars is because the price is reasonable, the staff was pleasant, and it was a cute looking restaurant.
column2234:
We could place an order after noon is too late as a busy office lunch order. The Uber Eats website does not accept any order in until restaurant's  open time.  We have ordered our office lunch today with my co-workers' recommendation. Since restaurant's opening time is so late, my lunch time ended up with after 3 PM. I can not use your restaurant again next time. It is too late to open for our businesses lunch time.  2nd, my order was quite different from my expectation. I ordered a Chicken Katsudon and a Hijiki Salad. Katsudon was not with chicken Katsu. It was a small chicken nugget bowl. Katsu supposed be covered with bread crumbs for the extra texture and crispiness. If you want to keep this menu ,you should change the name to more proper name. Then you can avoid any confusion with real Japanese food lovers. Hijiki salad, your web menu description says " Hijiki Salad: Black seaweed cooked with carrot, fried tofu, and edamame in our original dashi.
But what I got as a Hijiki Salad does not have any carrot, fried tofu. Edamame was 3-4 pieces on the top of the Hijiki as a garnishment only. I ordered for my better nutrition.   So, it was a big disappointment for me without any other vegetables. also, only Hijiki is a little tough to eat,(the nature of the Hijiki, I feel it is so dry. Hard to enjoy only Hijiki its self) even if I am a native Japanese. Thank you for reading this for me and your time.
column2235:
A very cute restaurant right next to Woodland park zoo. This place is stingy. We ordered a chicken karaage curry. It came with a whopping 3 piece of chicken of a size of a pinky lol. I kid you not. I am dead serious. And it's $14!  Also the karaage was burnt so after I removed the burnt portion I had probably 1 and half piece left lol. The price is OK but come on....I expect better portion? the taste is ok nothing exceptional. We also order the spicy poke bowl. It's not good. The vinegar is too overpowering and again very stingy on the fish and it was $16!? I could probably get better poke cheaper and tastier in a lot of other places.

Maybe I was in a bad mood with my main course, I found the dessert mediocre...  

In general they have decent tasting food but super stingy on portion with. The environment is very nice with natural breeze and soft jazz. I would definitely come again if they change owner. 

I honestly don't know how this place got such a a high rating.
column2236: My friend recommended this Japanese bistro near Green Lake to me and we had brunch here on Sunday. It was raining so we sat inside. I guess it would be really lovely to sit outside when it's sunny. We had sashimi salad, teriyaki salmon and curry. There four different kinds of fishes in the salad, all of which were fresh and tasted great. It was my first time seeing salmon going together with teriyaki sauce, and it turned out to be yummy. The set also included sushi rolls. The curry was authentic and we added karaage in it, which were juicy and tender. We had matcha shake and matcha latte for drink, and both of them were awesome. Good service and nice vibe. We really enjoyed the time here.
column2237:
I have been wanting to try out this place for awhile because I used to follow Setsuko's recipes on local Japanese community paper. I was... disappointed. It's not because of the taste of sweets, but by the atmosphere. 
I rode my bike there. I got sweaty because I had a climb to Phinney Ave from Green Lake. When I walked in with a helmet on, I probably saw 4 employees and a customer, but none said "hi." Then I heard "well, an interesting getup person just came in" in Japanese by the customer. After that, silence. No greeting whatsoever. I should have made sure to look at their face when I spoke and ordered what I wanted in Japanese (or just scolded them and walked out). 
The only saving grace was a Ballard HS student who works there because he is taking a Japanese class. He was polite unlike the rest of the adult employees. Shame on you, adults. I hope your snobby attitude isn't rubbing off on him.
column2238: This place was amazing! Such a cool little vibe. When you first walk in it's almost like a cafe because there's tea and a pastry case full of all kinds of goodies. But then there's also a sushi bar. Very fresh and flavorful. The poke bowl was amazing. I highly recommend the seared salmon nigiri as well as the caterpillar roll! Their miso was just what I needed on this rainy seattle day.
column2239:
Ever since I ordered a cake from them for my wedding, I've been wanting to try their food. I finally made it in and ordered their curry, tempura udon, happy hour edamame and sashimi. I really wanted to like them because their menu items are uniquely Japanese but alas, the entire experience was very underwhelming.

1. Japanese portions with Seattle prices. In other words, portions are tiny compared to what you pay.

2. Execution needs improvement: The edamame needed more salt and was over cooked. The tempura came out soggy. 

3. Service: Our waitress was nice and attentive, but she was not familiar with the menu. 

The curry was definitely the best dish, however it was standard curry that I could make a home. I would not pay $15 bucks again.

Their desserts are great. Stick to the desserts.
column2240:
Cute little restaurant in phinney ridge. It's nice to have a Japanese place in this neighborhood. I came in 10 minutes before closing for lunch.

$14.99 for a lunch special sashimi salad. It definitely wasn't what I was expecting. I too had high expectations for this restaurant. They gave me a box filled with bagged greens, 7 pieces of fish, and a tiny 1/4 filled sauce cup. Really?!

No wasabi and just a little sauce for this salad? I wasn't happy at all. I couldn't even go in to complain. 

Please be more generous with your salad dressing next time.
column2241:
I stopped in here during the Coronavirus. For Ballard, it is nice that there is plenty of parking.  Everyone was wearing masks and tables were at a comfortable business.  The interior is a little aged, but comfortable.  

They have a good beer selection.  The menu is interesting.  It has some typical bar food items, but then also waffles.

I ordered the Philly cheese steak and onion rings.  The food is really good.  The bread was softer than expected, but good.  The beef was nice and the mix of cheese with the peppers and onions was perfect.  The onion rings were good also.

I was with someone who had the seafood tacos--they were very nice at all, with some nice guacamole you could put on them.
column2242:
Went to Fremont Sunday market and stopped here for lunch. Large menu for food and drinks.  Immediatelyoved it because they not only allow dogs in but have menu for them.

It's a little run down but the people and food make up for it.

Had philly cheese steak with chops and Greek salad with chicken. Both were good. Salad dressing was sweet and tangy.  Lots of steak on the philly cheese hoagie.   The chips were ok but not much flavor.   I would pass and get tater  tots or fries instead. 

Friendly fun atmosphere.  Will be back to try brunch.
column2243:
I came here with coworkers because the restaurant across the street was closed. It's a pretty big restaurant for the Seattle area I feel like, so seating was comfortable even for a party of 5. I ordered the fried chicken sliders and got the fries. It actually took some time for the food to come out seeing as we got there when the place was pretty empty, but it did eventually fill up around noon. The sliders were ok, the chicken sliders come with a large nugget size of chicken with a pickle and of course the bun. There was no sauce on the sliders and the side of house ranch never came and I really didn't care to ask for it. I think the sauce was forgotten for every plate in the party. The fries were definitely the star of the show, very crispy and well seasoned, but the sliders besides being a decently fried chicken nugget were kinda dry and the pickle was nice, but some kind of sauce would have been nice. Overall it was just ok for me. I wouldn't go out of my way to come, but I'd be open to eating here. 

Also this has nothing to do with my rating, but be aware this restaurant is very dog friendly. There are semi free roaming dogs that patrons are allowed to bring in. While there are rules to the doggy visitors and all the dogs were on their best behaviors, it still makes me feel slightly uneasy. 

Again that's just a me thing and some people might enjoy this and some may not. To me it comes off as a bit unsanitary and maybe not good for a pet to be surrounded by loud stimulation? I'm not sure that's just an opinion of course, but something to be aware of.
column2244:
I ordered the chicken pesto sandwich with fries and no lettuce, and I was a bit unpleasantly surprised that the sandwich had not been toasted and the cheese and turkey was still cold. Would have been nice to know it was a cold sandwich so that I could have known to ask for it warmed up, but it was still a good sandwich! 

I think cheese is almost always better when it's melted, and so having the slices cold was not the ideal food experience but also it was different than what I'm used to which is always nice when figuring out if I actually do enjoy food in the way that I think I do, which in this case, I can verify, warm sandwiches are my preference.

The fries were nice and crispy, and they were a good mix of some super crispy bits with some nice and chewy ones. For a place that is so dog friendly I was pleasantly surprised to find the food so delicious!
column2245:
Menu doesn't have full info about the burgers and the staff working today basically insulted me to the head chef when i called to ask questions about the burger, heard him telling the chef what to tell me so he wouldn't be in the wrong like I couldn't hear him. I get its hard being essential right now, im essential to, however to  be a complete jerk is out of line. Also, trying to ask to speak to anyone in charge is a joke. They apparently are only there after 10p.

also after the mixup, no offer to remake the fucking food. or even a refund. here i am staring at burger i dont want to eat. and im out 20 fucking bux cuz i tipped well too.

*edit*
I wound up taking my burger back for a refund due to how horrid the service and quality was. As i was getting my refund processed an employee walked out of the kitchen to set folks food for the server to pickup and take to people and he was not wearing a mask. There wasn't even a mask under his chin or anywhere to be seen. Real safe during a global pandemic seeing an uptick in cases in the area that you live and work in buddy. Kinda glad I didn't eat your fucking food. and now i get to sanitize my apartment, thanks. dicks.
column2246:
It's a pawtttttyyyy! 

Been 6 months since I got my puppy. And we've been exploring. I do more takeouts and pup friendly spots. This was so fun for Baci! So many puppers!

We sat in the back since the front was quite full. I like the booths! Baci was skeptical!! 

The menu was typical: burgers! Fried food! Breakfast food! And the puppy menuuuuuu!! Woof woof. 

Baci got a bone marrow! Meatloaf! A lot of goodies that day!! Our server was a little too busy for our water and other stuff. But you can always flag someone else down. 

Food: I picked the heaviest dish ever! And it was heavy!! Had to order a burger to balance out! It was quite tasty!! Hope Baci liked his treats too!! Woof woof! 3 stars total but 1 extra star for being pawsome to my pup!
column2247:
Dog friendly, great happy hour, and great prices! This is my ALL TIME favorite dog friendly restaurant in all of Seattle + surrounding area.

They have a dog menu as well for our fluffies! 

Bonus points: awesome happy hour with lots of bar food!
column2248:
5 STARS FOR ALL OF THE DOGGY DECOR AND THE PLACE BEING DOG FRIENDLY. 

That is where the good ends, unfortunately. I wanted to love this place and really expected to based on reviews and on the fact that it is surrounded by dog everything. That is my life. Unfortunately, the food had some issues (I honestly mostly liked mine) and the servers made me wish they used pups instead of humans to take orders and serve food. They would do a way better job. 

What we ordered- I got the sour cream dill omelette over a bed of greens and their house potatoes. Enjoyed the eggs and dill, didn't eat the useless greens cuz lettuce is weird with eggs, and the potatoes has an okay flavor but they came out like warm and were still hard in the middle. 

Bestie got the eggs Benedict and had the same issue with the taters, and also the hollandaise sauce was very liquidy and citrusy. Weird. 

Husband got his favorite, chicken fried steak. He did really like the gravy... but didn't finish his meal (he ALWAYS finishes) because the meat was way too thick and firm and the potatoes were raw once again! Disappointing. 

I was going to still give 3-4 stars except then we had the dickiest servers. One bearded man who looked like he just woke up and was pissed to be there. He was not our server but since ours was never around we had to ask him twice for something as he walked by. He did not seem to like that. Whatever. 

It was our sever that I honestly wanted to slap. He was a bitchy guy in the worst way possible. He was annoyed when we asked anything and after saying "excuse me" 3 times when he walked by (he ignored me) I finally had to raise my voice from across the room to say "excuse me, we're ready to pay now." He then mumbled something angrily to himself. 

He had brought us the bill (who we had to ask sourpuss for cuz of course he was nowhere to be found) and then our server walked by our table twice and made eye contact with my husband in like a 15 minute period but wouldn't take our cards so we could get the hell out of there. Suffice to say, he clearly didn't like me getting his attention because when he came back with our receipts and cards, he literally dropped them on the corner of the table while looking straight ahead with a pouty look on his face. I said "thank you" loudly and he ignored me. Cool. 

It's like he was trying to do everything in his power to get a really terrible tip. Welp, he succeeded. And I'm an awesome tipper!

Also, a chick came in to start her shift and bitchy server was like "how's it going?" And she said (in the most depressing voice) "terribly" and then he did the loudest chortle ever. It just seems like because it's a laid back joint in Fremont they have that "we don't give a damn" attitude and they probably get away with it 95% of the time. But as a previous server, it's really not hard to be polite. Bubbly and super chipper? Not even necessary, just polite and willing to do your job. Ugh.
column2249: You're not coming here for the food. But if you are looking for an incredibly chill place to bring your pup and allow them to mingle with other dogs and people of the like this is a great stop. Servers work seamlessly through the distraction and lack of walkway space with all the dogs around :) Other diners are even super friendly and start up convos if your dogs connect or even if you just start to chat. Food itself is mainly just sandwiches, burgers etc for typical bar food.
column2250:
Love this place because of how dog friendly it is! Including a special menu just for pooches! Very friendly staff and can't help but to feel comfortable.
Food is so good and reasonably priced. Never walked out feeling like i broke the bank after some grub and a few drinks.
column2251: When I first sat down, I grabbed the table tent, much to my surprise, it was the doggie menu!!! What a statement! This made me feel comfortable... as well as my furbaby! Great burge for me... and my dog LOVED THE BOW WOW BEEF BOWL!!!
column2252:
Been to Norm's a number of times over the past 10 years and very recently it's become a place where good vibes go to die. 

This summer and fall in particular, the food has become nearly inedible (even at dive bar expectations).  Simultaneously, the food can be overcooked and still frozen. Twice I've ordered the bacon cheddar sliders and twice received different riffs on crap. Undercooked patties (both times), unmelted cheese sans bacon (once), old and undercooked fries (both times), and buns that were not even separated when plated but rather still stuck together. Seriously worried about what other food prep shortcuts are being taken...

The service itself does not exist. Sure, they'll take your order and bring you beer. That's it. Can't expect follow up, refills, or even anyone to bring the tab. Asking for the tab seems to be an imposition and if paying with card, you can expect the bad to continue. 

There is nothing worse to me than getting stuck staring at empty glasses, half eaten garbage on a plate, feeling like you have to force the servers to "let" you pay and move on. I would nope the F outta there as fast as possible if only I was able to pay for what I ordered.

But maybe it's not all bad for everyone: They don't seem to ID consistently. They didn't seem to mind that other patrons were ordering food from outside establishments (maybe these folks knew something we  didn't). And they didn't seem to care that a three-top ate, drank, and took off without settling their tab. I'm not into any of that, however, so I won't be back. 

Additionally, there are many other places in Fremont that happily allow dogs if that makes a difference.
column2253:
Been ages since I last visited Norm's but still as good as I remembered it!

Great chill atmosphere for brunch! There are tables, booths, bar top, and couches with a coffee table to choose from.

This is a puppy friendly establishment so expect lots of cuteness and love. They have a puppy menu that is pretty adorable. Our group had two dogs that were so excited for their chicken bowl and cheesy donuts.

I ordered their breakfast because who doesn't love breakfast?!?! Hubby and I split the tater tot poutine and NW Berries waffles. Waffles were crispy even with all the toppings. Poutine - good crunchy tots, lots of good cheese, not sure if it went well with their gravy.

We also ordered their brunch cocktails which were reasonably priced for Seattle, as well as their fried pickle FRIES! YES, you read that right. Their fried pickles are not your typical medallions. They're long slivers of pickles, deep fried to golden perfection, and served with a savory white sauce.

Not sure why I stopped going to Norm's but highly recommended for brunch for a big group, and four-legged friends.
column2254:
For being 4 stars on Yelp, I really expected to love Norm's! Unfortunately, I thought it was just okay. :/ 

What I REALLY love about this place can pretty much go unspoken, but I'll say it anyways - DOG FRIENDLY. Super dog friendly. They even have a menu for the pups! We ordered our lil guy a Bacon Pupcake (he only ate about half of it, but he was only 8 weeks so I'll give him a break).

Us hoomans ordered the Country Fried Steak and I believe my boyfriend got the Biscuits & Gravy. Honestly, I wasn't a big fan. The gravy that my steak was covered in was kind of bland, and I'm still sad that they didn't have Corned Beef Hash on the menu. That stuff is my JAM. 

Service was pretty friendly and the place itself had that hole-in-the-wall vibe, but I definitely liked it.

Heads up - don't pay for parking! We made that mistake and apparently they validate for you (or we think so, we saw somebody ask about it and receive a ticket of some sort).
column2255:
I've come here for Saturday nights, and they have karaoke! It's very lively with pretty good singers going up! There isn't a stage, but a small set up front at the windows. Night atmosphere and fun vibe. I love a place where I can eat (not just bar food, but actual food-food) and drink from a nice selection, and have a good show.

I think we all know that this place allows dogs here which is perfect for a lot of dog owners. They also have a dog menu too. The human menu serves classic diner food and other American classics. The food wasn't that bad. 

When we were there though, it seemed like the kitchen forgot my friend's order! They were super kind and comp the meal on the house AND our second round of alcohol was on then too! Great service!!
column2256: Jamming tunes- great beers and your best friend came come too?! (your dog obviously) Sign me up. Norms rocks.
column2257:
Woof! That's how excited I am, when coming into Norms! (You know, due to their dog friendly restaurant! ._. By god if you're a dog lover and not wagging your tail right now with excitement, you should start digging a hole in the backyard so I can scold you later for it.) May I say that this place is a safe haven for dog lovers everywhere and more examples of catching up with what crazy dog people want!! (Like when your grandma starts blasting Cardi B in her mini van with you for no reason at all.) So let's go on a "walk" with this review and bark on the right review. *crickets... * 

Atmosphere:
The layout to the furniture is a 1950s look and is quite pleasing to the eye. Its subtle and works for the place as unique brunch/barfood/dog friendly restaurant. (Whoa... o.o who is this guy? This is coming from the guy that put a big anime poster up in his room and thought it brought finesse to the room. [Well it did!!O.O]) With a warm atmosphere, it's perfect temperature for any customer and hairy companion (Not you sasquatch. Sorry buddy maybe they'll open one for sasquatch friendly soon!) to come in and grab a bite to eat. The quirky decorations of different dog art of frames on the wall tie the bow around this restuarant very well. (Side note: if you put a bow on anything it's a present, so if your a hoarder that's come to terms to give up there stuff but too cheap to pay for the garbage bill. Put a bow on it and give it to your friends!) The bar to you right is clean and stocked up with a great varieties of poison you choose your little heart to decide on. (But let's be honest we mostly go to see how clean it is. Right? ._.) For dog friendly, it is in great keep of cleanliness. (Which I say to your staff: "What sort of black magic have you conjured?!?!?)

Customer service:
May only be described as excellent. Always within earshot. (Or is it ear shout? Damn you English! .-. for being my second language.) The lady that was attending us was super kind! (With a voice that could be described as a loving mother in a Disney movie. [If I had to choose:101 Dalmations.]) She was knowledgeable of most dogs there and was friendly around them. (Which shows she was a dog lover. [How weird would it be to work there while not loving dogs and allergic to them? That's why you never lie on your resume!]) 

Food/Drinks:
Sadly I didn't have the luxury of eating here. (Due to eating somewhere else, but from what I saw the food smelled great! [And as you can guess I have a keen nose... ._. Dont quote me on that.]) But from the drinks everyone had and food around me I could say that I will definitely have to come back here. As well as doggy menu for your dog! (Which my poodle still resents me for not taking him here.) They do have brunch! So if you ever want to bro down with your HBF (hairy bestfriend) this is definitely a pit stop. 

Conclusion: 
I had a water... but it was the best glass ever (it was beautiful... *tear*) that was made that way do to the dog friendly atmosphere, caring community  and customer service. Now have the luxury of drinking in public and getting intoxicated in front of your HBF. (While he looks around saying he was "adopted" and gets you an UBER) A definite must for dog lovers and people that one day wait for a sasquatch friendly environment too. ^-^
column2258:
A-OK!
You can't go wrong with a place that has dogs everywhere!

Came in on a Saturday for lunch. Was able to get a seat at the bar right away. Staff overall was friendly, the sports games were on, and all was well. I decided to order the "Americana" burger...essentially a bacon cheese burger w/1000 island on it. When the food came out, the burger was sadly missing the bacon and the 1000 island dressing. The kitchen corrected, and all in all the burger was OK tasting. The fries would have been better had they not been cold and not quite crispy enough. For $15 I was a little disappointed. 
Plenty of beers on tap and full bar. Dogs, seriously everywhere. At one time I counted a dozen. For me, it was a fun atmosphere. Prices are a little high overall and for the quality of food. I would return for some drinks and/or perhaps brunch.
column2259:
This is exactly what all "dog-friendly" restaurants should aspire to be. They have many barkery items for you to choose from for your pup. And they allow your dogs inside (not just outside on a patio).
The had a sandwich, fried pickles, and cheese curds and enjoyed everything. They have a good selection of beers on tap too. Our server was super friendly.
column2260:
Came here for trivia because it was advertised on Facebook for 7pm. It was actually at 8pm. At least I got to catch the happy hour menu.

It's your typical bar food and brews. 

I do like the pups that are all around. Someday I will try the animal style burger, but $15 is too rich for my blood when I could go to in n out burger for like $4.
column2261:
During Covid, this bar opens at 9am on Sunday's and has wide open spaces to watch football.  There currently is no sitting at the bar but there we're plenty of tables available.
They have a new drink called the Kraken, in support of Seattle's new NHL team and it was DELICIOUS! 
We showed our Kraken pride and ordered this drink. It is a mixture of lemonade, blue curacao, rum and lime and it was truly amazing! 
The bar tender was a bit busy but he was very friendly during our interactions.
column2262:
Awesome space, there's plenty of seating with large glass windows to give you the outdoor feel but still enclosed for those cold evening breezes! 

They have great empanadas and when their game room was opened (pre Covid) we would always bring out of town guests here. 

My company had a party here once and it was upstairs. There's plenty of space and the atmosphere/crowd is great.
column2263: I love this spot! I always stay around lake Union when I'm in the area for work, and this is my go to. They are always so friendly and everything is amazing! COVID and all, you feel comfortable and welcomed. This is the place to be!
column2264:
Good vibe to hang out with others, and stand around but not the best place to watch a UFC fight. Also, there's not nearly enough seating for everyone, so that's also somewhat of a pain here (especially if you're planning on watching a few hours of prelims plus the main card)

Food: pretty good! I got some garlic fries and wings and was impressed with it being bar food. It wasn't the best but I wasn't hungry after!

Vibe: there's lots of things to do here, darts, games, pool, etc. the big problem is getting a free spot to sit. 

UFC: I was definitely excited to hear that they were showing the UFC fight here, but I honestly don't think it was the best environment if you actually want to watch. Yes it's a great bonding experience and vibe to hang out with others, but theres no seating, a lack of TVs in my opinion, and the volume is not high enough. I just wanted them to turn up the volume!! Also the tv cut out a couple of times. Next time I want to see a UFC fight, I may just go to Buffalo Wild Wings.
column2265:
I don't give out 5 stars often but this place deserves it!  Not for the food or atmosphere (although those two weren't terrible..) but mainly for the service.  We came here for dinner because I am SUPER picky (health nut and dietary restrictions) and my mom is equally picky in her own way (think doesn't like to try new things...)  We thought the menu here looked do-able for us both.

The atmosphere is fun and I would probably come back to host an event here or even if I was staying in Seattle and wanted to go out and play games (one side of the establishment is dedicated to just that!)  The location is great, and there seems like to be something for everyone (TVs for sports, pool, arcade games, and more!
